entry.title: Comment 9
entry.content:
Depends where your polipo is listening.

I use polipo with its default port of 8123, so in my Torbutton preferences I
selected "Use custom proxy settings" and put in localhost 8123 for http and
https proxies, and left localhost 9050 for socks.

You're right that when we switch the packages from including privoxy to
including polipo, we'll want to make sure that the Torbutton that's included
knows what port it should tell Firefox to proxy to.

The easy answer is to configure the polipo we ship so that it listens on port
8118. The only downside is that it will conflict if you have Privoxy installed too.

I had posted twice as Anonymous.

Unfortunately, at least the last few versions of Vidalia have been unstable on my PowerBook G4/10.5.6. I thrashed this package and installed the latest stable Tor and Polipo. Changed these settings in Polipo's config and the setup works:

entry.title: Comment 13
entry.content:
From the post itself, this is experimental. I warned you it might not work, might crash, might sour your milk. It assumed a clean install. if you have a ~/.vidalia or ~/Library/Vidalia directory, it won't work after drag and drop. you will have to change the paths.

As for polipo, diskcache is disabled, otherwise it records every site you've visited through polipo. This is not good for anonymity.

Memory cache is enabled to improve performance.

entry.title: Comment 15
entry.content:
I should have mentioned that I would love nothing better than to simply drag the Vidalia package and have it "work out of the box." However, as some others had to I had to change the path, probably because I had used privoxy, etc before. Bigger headache is that Vidalia becomes unresponsive too often.

I heard from the developer of PolipoStatusBar that his server crashed and he has not found a new "home" for his app. Meanwhile, I came across Dolipo. It is a GUI wrapper for polipo. I installed polipo and am now using tor with Dolipo.

If you are having trouble with this Vidalia package, you may want to take a look at a Dolipo (menu bar based) and Tor setup. In the Dolipo preferences, you can select the Polipo config file and toward the bottom enter localhost:9050 for Socks Parent Proxy. Tweak other settings you like and you are on your way. Only issue is having to manually configure relaying, if you want to do that.

entry.title: Comment 18
entry.content:
The Tor Browser Bundle actually includes Polipo, not Privoxy. Polipo is a lighter-weight proxy that serves pretty much the same role as Privoxy. It just runs in the background, and Vidalia launches it when everything starts up.

(Privoxy is a little bit better than Polipo at removing dangerous web stuff, but Torbutton 1.2 does a fine job at that, so the fact that Privoxy can do some of it is moot.)

entry.title: Comment 20
entry.content:
My bundle didn't work out of the box, until I discovered that polipo was running its default configuration, rather than the one provided by the Vidalia bundle.

The solution was to open Vidalia's preferences, and under "Proxy Application Arguments" in the General tab to add the following:

-c /Applications/Vidalia.app/Contents/Resources/polipo.conf

Then everything worked perfectly.
